posts.title: Introducing NYPL's Best Books of 2021
posts.text: The nearly century-long tradition of NYPL librarians choosing the best books of the year acknowledges important, impactful writing and connects New Yorkers with books that spark a true love of reading... and can help with holiday shopping! There is something on this list for everyone!

posts.title: Don’t Go In There! Haunted Spaces & Places
posts.text: Whether it's a graveyard at midnight or an abandoned asylum, spending time in some places takes more guts than sense. Here are a few different takes on the classic theme of haunted spaces and places.

posts.title: Summer 2021 Staff Picks for All Ages
posts.text: Summer staff picks for the beach, the pool, the plane and all places between.

posts.title: Top Five Beverly Cleary Books
posts.text: “Don’t stop now. Go ahead! Be readers all of your lives. And don’t forget, librarians and teachers can help you find the right books to read.” We couldn’t agree more, Beverly Cleary. Thanks for all you’ve given us.

posts.title: Your Voice Counts: Why Voting Matters Book List
posts.text: Check out this list of books about the history of New York City politics and how citizens have made a great impact over time. Read, learn, and get ready to vote!

posts.title: NYPL’s Jennie Maas Flexner: The Reader’s Champion
posts.text: Flexner was an early advocate of the library concept of a reader-centered philosophy and believed that reading the right book at the right time will foster a sense of satisfaction and joy in the reader.

posts.title: Lista de lectura de las elecciones de 2020
posts.text: Toma una decisión informada. Lea como si su voto dependiera de ello.

posts.title: Books to Get Kids Excited About Voting & Elections
posts.text: These picture books will introduce kids to the importance of voting and help kids feel a part of the election buzz.

posts.title: Summer Reading Is For Adults, Too
posts.text: No matter your plans, here are some books that scream summer vacation.

posts.title: Book Recommendations from Our Lions, Patience & Fortitude
posts.text: In celebration of their birthday, our lions have put together reading recommendations that inspire the qualities for which they are named.

posts.title: Books To Make That 30 Minute Independent Reading Time Fly By
posts.text: Keep them reading well past their required time.

posts.title: Middle Grade Fiction You Can Read at Home
posts.text: Great reads available in e-book format from the Library.

posts.title: Perfect Stay At Home Books to Fuel a Hobby or Project
posts.text: NYPL staffers are using these books to help with home improvements, self-improvements, cooking, crafting and much more.

posts.text: Murder, mayhem and madness...

posts.title: Resources to Support Distance Learning
posts.text: Including some that are normally only available at the Library.

posts.title: Audio Books to Try While You Work From Home
posts.text: Are you missing your designated reading time now that you're not commuting to work?

posts.title: Popular Books You Keep Meaning to Read (All Available as E-Books, Too)

posts.title: 125 Books We Love: 5 Books That Are Hidden Gems Ready to Be Discovered

posts.title: 125 Books We Love: 7 Books to Help Lapsed Readers Get Back Into Reading
posts.text: These books will draw you in, excite you, and set you back on the reading path.

posts.title: NYPL Top Checkouts of 2019
posts.text: Curious what other New Yorkers were reading this year? Here are the top 10 checkouts systemwide for each of our three boroughs: the Bronx, Manhattan and Staten Island as well as the most checked out book of the year systemwide.

posts.title: Introducing NYPL's Best Books of 2019
posts.text: The New York Public Library is thrilled to announce our Best Books of 2019, a curated selection of recommended reads for kids, teens, and adults, selected by our expert librarians!

posts.title: Best Illustrated Children’s Books of 2019
posts.text: Let's face it, picture books are not just for kids.

posts.title: NYPL's Top 10 Books of 2019
posts.text: We asked our staff of voracious readers here at NYPL to send us the titles they read and loved published between January and December 2019. The results were as diverse as our staff and collections, but these are the ten that received the greatest number of votes. Friends and readers, NYPL’s Top 10 Books of 2019.

posts.title: 12 Authors and Their TED Talks
posts.text: Ever wondered if your favorite author has a TED Talk? In honor of the #TEDReads initiative and National Book Month, check out these twelve authors who have given TED Talks.

posts.title: Read NYPL Insta Novels
posts.text: The New York Public Library's Insta Novels program was nominated for three Webby Awards.​ The Insta Novels program, created by independent advertising and creative agency Mother in New York and developed in partnership with the Library, aims to make these stories more widely available, reach new audiences, and turn a space for fleeting interactions into one for immersive reading.

posts.title: Go Your Own Way
posts.text: This fall Warby Parker is helping to support our Early Literacy Initiative. As it turns out, they love reading as much as we do! In particular, titles featuring characters who blaze their own trail, march to the beat of their own drummer, and go their own way.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: YA Nonfiction
posts.text: Some exceptional new nonfiction titles for teens available on shelves in local libraries everywhere.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Middle-Grade Fiction
posts.text: Our experts have been busy reading all the middle school novels 2019 has to offer and here are a few they can't stop giving to kids across our three boroughs.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Picture Books
posts.text: Picture books are amazing! I’m not sure who loves them more, kids or adults. Here are some exceptional new ones coming to a library shelf near you.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: YA Fiction
posts.text: Our Best Books for Teens committee is hard at work finding great books and putting them in the hands of teens around the city. Here are a few they are excited to share.

posts.title: Words Without Borders: Books for World Refugee Day
posts.text: A New York Public Library & UNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency, Staff Picks List Honoring Voices of the Forcibly Displaced on #WorldRefugeeDay

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Nonfiction for Kids
posts.text: Our Best Books for Kids committee has been busy! Here are some nonfiction titles they are shouting about from library roofs across the city.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Middle Grade Fiction
posts.text: Middle-grade fiction is on fire! There are so many new books. Luckily we have an expert staff of readers to help direct us to the cream of the crop. Here are some recently published titles they recommend.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: YA Graphic Novels
posts.text: There are so many great graphic novels for teens it is hard to keep up. Luckily, here at NYPL, we have a team of experts doing the work for us.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy Nonfiction for Kids
posts.text: Kids love nonfiction. Their little brains are like sponges. They yearn for facts and stories from history. It's even better when it's presented in an engaging package.

posts.title: Vote Now: NYPL's Insta Novels Nominated for Webbys
posts.text: The New York Public Library's Insta Novels program was nominated for three Webby Awards.​ The Insta Novels program, created by independent advertising and creative agency Mother in New York and developed in partnership with the Library, aims to make these stories more widely available, reach new audiences, and turn a space for fleeting interactions into one for immersive reading.

posts.title: Albertine Prize 2019
posts.text: The Albertine Prize aims to introduce American readers to contemporary French literature in translation. From April 4 to 30, readers all over the world will be able to vote on Albertine.com for their favorite book among the selected titles. On June 5, we’ll celebrate the winning book with a ceremony at Albertine Books in New York City.

posts.title: A Walt Whitman Reading List
posts.text: Walt Whitman has been called America’s “bard of democracy.”  His life’s work, Leaves of Grass, ushered in a new and unconventional style of unrhymed verse. The New York Public Library will celebrate the bicentennial of the iconic writer’s birth with an exhibition that honors Whitman’s impact on America and examines the many influences that shaped his writing.

posts.title: A Lou Reed Reading List
posts.text:
"I always believed that I have something to say and I said it." —Lou Reed
The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts is thrilled to announce that beginning March 15, 2019, the Lou Reed Archive has been processed and is now available to users.

posts.title: Memoirs to Celebrate Black History
posts.text: Black History Month began in the United States in 1970 as a way to remember and honor the prominent figures and events in the history of the African Diaspora. Today, we have the opportunity to read about the legacy of slavery in America straight from these writers who have lived with it.

posts.title: 2019 Winners: Carnegie & Notable Book Awards
posts.text: The American Library Association announced the winners of their prestigious 2019 Carnegie and Notable Books at the Midwinter meeting in Seattle.

posts.title: 2019 Winners: Newbery, Caldecott, King, Printz & More
posts.text: The American Library Association announced the winners of their prestigious 2019 Youth Media Awards at the Midwinter meeting in Seattle.

posts.title: NYPL Celebrates 175th Anniversary of A Christmas Carol with Insta Novels and Podcast
posts.text: To celebrate the 175th anniversary of the book's publication, The New York Public Library released a surprise edition of Insta Novels: A Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens. The Library also rebroadcast one of its most popular podcast episodes featuring Neil Gaiman reading from Charles Dickens's own prompt copy of A Christmas Carol.

posts.title: NYPL Top Checkouts of 2018
posts.text: Every year we compile The New York Public Library's top 10 checkouts, both system-wide and for each of our three boroughs: The Bronx, Staten Island, and Manhattan. Here are the books that readers checked out the most in 2018.

posts.title: Read The Metamorphosis on Instagram Stories, the Latest Edition of Insta Novels
posts.text: The New York Public Library released another edition of Insta Novels: The Metamorphosis, a novella by Franz Kafka illustrated by César Pelizer (@cesarpelizer). The Metamorphosis is available to read on the Library's Instagram account  (@nypl).

posts.title: 29 Years From the Fall: KGB and Cold War Reads
posts.text: On November 9, 1989, the Berlin Wall fell, effectively and symbolically ending the Cold War. Twenty-nine years later, we're still making sense of the decades of fear and east-west divisions. One need only watch FX's The Americans to see that the Cold War is still alive and well in the American imagination. As we look back at The Fall, here are the books we'll be reading.

posts.title: The Raven Lands on Insta Novels for Halloween
posts.text: Today The New York Public Library released the latest installment of Insta Novels: "The Raven" a poem by Edgar Allan Poem. The story was illustrated by Studio Aka (@studioaka)  and is available to read on the Library's Instagram account (@nypl).

posts.title: Insta Novels: "The Yellow Wallpaper" Comes to Instagram Stories
posts.text: Today The New York Public Library released the latest installment of Insta Novels: "The Yellow Wallpaper," a short story by Charlotte Perkins Gilman. The story was illustrated by Buck (@buck_design) and is available to read on the Library's Instagram account (@nypl).

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Picture Books We Love
posts.text: Picture books are most often aimed at small children, but adults love them too. Here are a few new ones we recommend to readers of all ages.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Young Adult
posts.text: Young adult titles that are new to our collection and receiving favorable reviews from our Best Books for Teens committee.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Nonfiction for Kids
posts.text: New nonfiction for kids from three and up.

posts.title: Make Me Laugh: The Epic Librarian List of Funny Books for Kids
posts.text: When asked what they want from a book, parents most often say they want a book to build character or inspire goodness in their child. You know what kids want? Something to make them laugh. Let's give them what they want. Our staff name their young patrons' laugh-out-loud favorites.

posts.title: Nonfiction Genre Primer
posts.text: Nonfiction is the broadest category of literature. Essentially, anything that is not fiction, poetry, or drama lives in the nonfiction section. These books range widely from memoir to history to how-to. The following post is a short introduction to the primary categories within nonfiction.

posts.title: The Season's Hottest Books & Some Readalikes
posts.text: There are a some books that set the world on fire when the come out, and our collections team does their best to satisfy, but sometimes we need to put our patrons in a holds queue. However, there is no need for anyone to leave the library empty-handed. Here are some of the season's hottest books and some titles with similar appeal to give them while they wait.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Fairy Tales, Poetry, and Graphic Novels for Kids
posts.text: Our Best Books for Kids committee is hard at work, narrowing down the vast pool of new books. Here are some fairy tales, poetry, and graphic novels that are getting good reviews.  Look for them on the shelves in your local library and test them out with your kids.

posts.title: If You Liked Big Little Lies, Try These...
posts.text: For fans of Big Little Lies by Liane Moriarty, here are more stories of suburban malaise and drama.

posts.title: If You Liked A Game of Thrones, Try These...
posts.text: For fans of A Game of Thrones by George R.R. Martin, here are more epic, world-building fantasy novels.

posts.title: If You Liked My Brilliant Friend, Try These...
posts.text: For fans of My Brilliant Friend by Elena Ferrante, here are more character-driven, reflective novels, with a strong sense of place.

posts.title: If You Liked The Leftovers, Try These...
posts.text: If you liked The Leftovers by Tom Perrotta, here are more apocalyptic novels.

posts.title: If You Liked Sharp Objects, Try These...
posts.text: For fans of Sharp Objects by Gillian Flynn, here are more disturbing psychological suspense novels.

posts.title: One Book, One New York and the winner is....
posts.text: One Book, One New York is in its second year and we are so happy to be supporting it here at the Library. If you are not familiar, One Book One New York is a program in which residents of all five boroughs are encouraged to read the same book at the same time.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New & Noteworthy for Teens
posts.text: Here are some recently published titles that are getting praise from our YA specialists here at NYPL. Pick them up for your teen or yourself!

posts.title: 2018 Albertine Prize Shortlist: Cast Your Vote!
posts.text: The second annual Albertine Prize, a reader’s choice award for best French fiction, is calling all fiction enthusiasts to vote in support of their favorite work of contemporary French fiction in English translation before May 1st!

posts.title: One Book, One New York
posts.text: The five finalists for One Book, One New York 2018 have been announced! Vote, all through the month of April, for the one you want to read along with your fellow New Yorkers. The winner will be announced May 3rd. All titles are available in both print and ebook format.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Nonfiction for Kids
New & Noteworthy: Picture Books
posts.text: Some picture books teach children (and remind adults) about what matters most. Here are a few new ones we think do this exceptionally well.

posts.text: This year has a lot to offer YA readers so far. Here are a few books our staff here at NYPL are calling out as special.

posts.title: LIVE from the NYPL: A Spring Season Reading List
posts.text: This spring, read along with the LIVE from the NYPL, a series of conversations with notable thinkers, writers, activists, and artists.

posts.title: ALA Award Winners 2018: Carnegie, Notables, & The Reading List
posts.text: Looking for something good to read? Here are the 2017 books librarians from across the country recommend.

posts.title: Most-Anticipated Adult Books of 2018
posts.text: We asked our adult specialists which books due out in 2018 they are most looking forward to reading, and here is what they said.

posts.title: Memoirs To Read In Your Lifetime
posts.text: A memoir is a collection of memories. The author may focus on a particular period in their life, or an event, or a relationship, but they are always reflective and often very candid. Beyond that, anything goes, and they are wide-ranging in style and tone. Here are a few you may enjoy.

posts.title: Counterculture Reading List
posts.text: Coinciding with the 50th anniversary of 1968, the Library is hosting events exploring the many cultural changes that emerged from 1960–74. You can also travel back to the sixties in the magic time machine that is literature.

posts.title: NYPL Top Checkouts of 2017
posts.text: Every year we compile The New York Public Library's top 10 checkouts, both system-wide and for each of  our three boroughs: The Bronx, Staten Island, and Manhattan. Here is the list for your enjoyment.

posts.title: NYPL's 10 Best Books of 2017
posts.text: NYPL staff votes for their favorite books published in 2017.

posts.title: 10 Best Illustrated Children's Books 2017!
posts.text: Today, the New York Times Book Review published their annual 10 Best Illustrated Children’s Books of 2017.  This is the 65th year this award has been given and for the first time the award was given jointly by The New York Public Library and The Times. We couldn’t be more excited about this collaboration or more proud of this list of gorgeous picture books.

posts.title: A Tribute to Tom Petty
posts.text: We are so saddened to learn of Tom Petty's passing. Such a singular talent and voice.  No words, just thanks.

posts.title: Banned Books Week 2017
posts.text: The Library is supporting the American Library Association's Banned Books Week—which honors the right to read—from September 24-30, 2017. If you want to join us in standing up for freedom of information, here’s how.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Superhero Stories
posts.text: Here are a few exceptional new superhero stories. May justice prevail!

posts.title: Fabulous Fall Staff Picks
posts.text: Fall is a magical time of year in New York City, but don't blink or you will miss it! We suggest you grab a good book and spend a day on a bench in Central Park.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Historical Middle Grade Fiction
posts.text: Until time travel becomes a reality for us all, fiction is the best way we know to and experience historical times.  Here are six exceptional new works of middle grade fiction, all set in times before today.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Culturally Diverse Middle Grade
posts.text: These are exactly the kind of books that will teach our next generation to be accepting and open-minded.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Selected Shorts
posts.text: Check out some new books we recommend in the form of the Short Story Cycle.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Nonfiction for Kids
posts.text: For all those young readers out there, some great new science writing on the ocean, and the planets, and the moon,  and a couple of noteable biographies.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy Nonfiction
posts.text: If you are looking for a serious book for the beach this season—we hear that is a thing since Lin Manuel Miranda read the Hamilton biography on vacation—here are a few we recommend.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New & Notable: Little Gems
posts.text: There is something special about a 200-250 page book. The story has a tight scope, the writing is often spare and concise, and the experience of reading it is discrete and memorable. Here are a few little gems we recommend.

posts.title: Best Translated French Fiction: Announcing the Albertine Prize Finalists
posts.text: Aiming to celebrate the best of contemporary French-language literature, Albertine, the bookshop of the Cultural Services of the French Embassy, has revealed the shortlist for the inaugural Albertine Prize, an annual award honoring the author and the translator of one Francophone novel published in the U.S. over the past year.

posts.title: Book Expo 2017: Back in NYC!
posts.text: Book Expo returns to the Javits center this year and runs from from Wednesday, May 31, through Friday, June 2, with the fourth annual Book Con, a consumer-facing, gathering for book fans, happening Saturday, June 3, and Sunday, June 4. Happy to have you home Book Expo.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New Picture Books
posts.text: Picture books are delightful for kids of all ages. Here are a few we think are extra-special.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New Middle Grade Fiction
posts.text: I can't stop marveling at the amazing Middle Grade Fiction being published these days. There is something for everyone and here are a few new titles we recommend.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New YA Fiction
posts.text: There is some great new fiction for teens coming out this Spring! Here are a seven titles at the top of our to-read piles here at NYPL.

posts.title: 14 New Poetry Picks for World Poetry Day
posts.text: Happy World Poetry Day! There has been a lot of good stuff since Yeats. Get current with these contemporary poetry recommendations.

posts.title: 7 Books About Twins For the Carters

posts.text: Come join us for RoboTakeover at NYPL, a hands-on robotics workshop for kids, at a branch near you.

posts.title: Books Written at The New York Public Library
posts.text: The New York Public Library's iconic Rose Main Reading Room at the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building reopened in October 2016 after a two-year closure for repairs and restorations. Since its opening in 1911, the Reading Room has served as a valuable resource for researchers, scholars, and writers. In honor of this morning's Reading Room reopening, we look at some of the books whose authors have acknowledged writing or researching at the Schwarzman Building over the years.

posts.title: Books for Fans of Law & Order
posts.text: Here are a few colorful detectives and crime/thriller/mystery series from NYPL staff for all you crime drama fans.

posts.title: Microhistories and Their Microtitles
posts.text: A somewhat recent and interesting approach to studying and writing about cultural and social history is the “microhistory.” We noticed a theme among microhistories: many have single word titles followed by a descriptive subtitle. Check out our list of microhistories and their microtitles.

posts.title: YA Books: Conversations About Consent
posts.text: In the wake of the Brock Turner case and its controversial aftermath, parents across the country are taking a more active role in teaching their teens about consent. If you are looking to jump-start a conversation about consent, consider reading one of the books below with your teen.

posts.title: The BFG: Steven Spielberg Meets Roald Dahl
posts.text: Steven Spielberg, creator of many beloved movies for children brings one of the most beloved children’s stories, The BFG by Roald Dahl, to the big screen. The BFG opens in theaters July 1, 2016 the year that marks the 100th anniversary of Dahl’s birth. To celebrate this collaboration, here are five of our favorite Dahl books, and five equally imaginative and magical Spielberg kids movies.

posts.text: Many books from Science and Science Fiction genres foretell the future and serve as cautionary tales that demand we think about our actions and the way we live today.

posts.text: Who would have imagined a trend in YA literature toward realistic, character-driven, and emotionally intense stories? If that is up your alley, we have some recommendations for you.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New Picture Books - The Animal Edition
posts.text: Our staff have been busy reading and reviewing this year's picture books. Here are a few of their favorites featuring animals to teach kids about, well, animals—but also some other important life lessons.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New Picture Books
posts.text: Our children's librarians have been busy reading and reviewing this year's picture books. Check out a few of their favorites.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: June 5, 2016
posts.text: If you are among the many readers who bought and read one of these five titles and want more of the same adventure or romance or thrills, here are some suggestions for you.

posts.text: Check out our list of offbeat, character-driven, intricately plotted, suspense novels set in the Midwest.

posts.text: Join us from 10-11 AM EDT for live reading recommendations on Twitter @NYPLRecommends!

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: May 23, 2016
posts.text: Here are some read alikes for the top five bestselling fiction titles this week.

posts.title: #FridayReads Roundup: Superheroes and Silicon Valley
posts.text: What we're reading this week.

posts.title: Women Made Women Superheroes
posts.text: Superheroes are all over the media these days. There is the Marvel series on Netflix.  Captain America: Civil War, Batman V. Superman: Dawn of Justice, and X-Men Apocalypse are all competing for ticket sales in movie theaters across America. On TV, viewers can followThe Flash (CW), The Arrow (CW), and Marvel's Agents of  S.H.I.E.L.D (ABC).

posts.title: For Fans of HBO's Silicon Valley
posts.text: For fans of HBO’s Silicon Valley, here are a few books that will satisfy the urge for social commentary and satire aimed at start-ups, social media, and tech culture in general.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: May 22, 2016
posts.text: Several titles from the thriller, suspense, and mystery categories are in the top five this week.

posts.title: #FridayRead Roundup: Seed Your Bookshelf to Trap a Librarian Friend, Literary Limericks, Uprisings, and New MG and YA Fiction
posts.text: Join us from 10-11 AM EDT for live reading recommendations on Twitter @NYPLRecommends!

posts.title: Readathon Reading Suggestions
posts.text: Join The New York Public Library and your fellow readers across the country for the second annual National Readathon Day on May 21.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New YA Fiction
posts.text: 2016 is serving up a feast of new YA fiction. Browse titles NYPL staff recommend.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New Middle Grade Fiction
posts.text: We are not quite half way through the year, and already 2016 is offering a feast of exceptional middle grade fiction.

posts.title: Uprisings
posts.text: A list of books about some recent uprisings that may one day be seen as tipping points.

posts.title: More Political Humor After the White House Correspondents' Dinner
posts.text: Humor across the political spectrum.

posts.title: Fantastic Magical Mysterious New Middle Grade Fiction
posts.text: Eight new middle grade titles to satisfy readers who long for a little mystery and a touch of the fantastic in their fiction.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: May 8, 2016
posts.text: The top five is full of romance again this week. For readers who are feeling a bit edgier, there is a new David Baldacci adreneline ride in the mix as well.

posts.title: In Memory of Prince
posts.text: We are saddened by the news of the passing of iconic musician and performer Prince. Thank you, Prince, for all you gave us. Here are a few of our favorites available on CD at the Library.

posts.title: Exceptional New Young Readers
posts.text: A few exceptional young readers for kids in 3rd through 5th grade.

posts.title: And the Winner Is ... Pulitzer 2016
posts.text: The Pulitzer Prize was established in 1917 by Joseph Pulitzer, an Hungarian-born American who made a forture as a newspaper publisher.  Here are this year's winners and finalists in the category of Letters, Drama, and Music.

posts.title: The Panama Papers: Fictional Characters We Suspect May Have Offshore Accounts
posts.text: Unless you have been living under a rock this month, you have surely heard about The Panama Papers, the biggest secret data leak in history. Here are a few fictional characters we are pretty sure would be implicated.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: April 17, 2016
posts.text: The top five bestselling fiction titles include: a thriller full of secrets and lies, a banter-filled regency romance, even more British romance, family drama, and an historic mystery.

posts.title: The Bernstein Awards: Meet the Finalists
posts.text: The Helen Bernstein Book Award for Excellence in Journalism annually honors a journalist whose books have brought clarity and public attention to important issues, events, or policies. Meet this year’s shortlist, with a few words from the committee members.

posts.title: #FridayReads Roundup: The Little Prince, Election Buzz & Journalists on ISIS
posts.text: Looking for a great book? Join us on Twitter this morning @NYPLRecommends from 10-11 AM. The Librarian is IN: taking requests and giving recommendations.

posts.title: Journalists on ISIS
posts.text: If you are wondering how this group got to the point of being organized, strategic, and growing steadily in numbers, these journalists can help you sort it all out.

posts.title: Happy Birthday To The Little Prince
posts.text: The Little Prince, a novella, by Antoine de Saint-Exupery was first published on April 6, 1943. If you read and loved it, here are a few other titles that are fantastic, magical, whimsical, perfect for the 9-12 year old set, and also feature princes.

posts.title: #FridayReads Roundup: Pakistan, Female Rockers, & Honoring Shakespeare
posts.text: Looking for a great book? Join us on Twitter @NYPLRecommends from 10-11 AM. The Librarian is IN: taking requests and giving recommendations.

posts.title: 30 Days of Shakespeare
posts.text: We asked thirty staff members to select and read their favorite Shakespeare speech, monologue, or sonnet. We will release one each day throughout the month of April.

posts.title: In Praise of Female Rock Memoirs
posts.text: Several great female memoirs have been published since Patti Smith's phenomenally successful Just Kids. Here's to the rise of the female rock memoir.

posts.title: #1000BlackGirlBooks Founder Marley Dias Joins Us at NYPL
posts.text: The New York Public Library's iconic Stephen A. Schwarzman Building had a special guest on Friday, March 25: 11-year-old Marley Dias, the pint-sized powerhouse behind #1000BlackGirlBooks, an initiative to encourage more diversity in books for children and teens.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: March 27, 2016
posts.text: The top five this week includes something for everyone: urban fantasy, gritty suspense fiction, a new police procedural, a little bit of romance, and some history. Happy reading!

posts.title: #FridayReads Roundup: Hello and What's New
posts.text: Looking for a great book? Join us on Twitter this morning @NYPLRecommends from 10-11 AM. The Librarian is IN: taking requests and giving recommendations.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New Picture Books
posts.text: We have been seeing some wonderful new picture books on our shelves recently. Here are a few of our favorites:

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New Middle Grade Books
posts.text: Spring titles are still on the horizon, but already we are seeing some wonderful new middle grade fiction titles. Here are a few we think are exceptional.

posts.title: #FridayReads Reading Roundup: Suffragettes, Feminisms, and Young Womyn Detectives
posts.text: A big shout-out for Women's History Month from us here at NYPL Recommends!

posts.title: Know Your Feminisms
posts.text: March is women's history month: a time to reflect on the lives and accomplishments of women and their contributions in history and in contemporary society. Who better to honor this March than history's influential feminists?

posts.title: Well Done, Sister Suffragette!
posts.text: Happy International Women's Day! We've compiled a list of powerful women who helped fight for women's rights.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: March 13, 2016
posts.text: It's a good week for romances: British romance, upbeat romance, and steamy paranormal romance. And it's not even spring yet!

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: March 4, 2016
posts.text: From sweet, heartfelt romance to steamy tales of rommates in a summer home, the top five really runs the romance gamut this week. Plus, some historical fiction and twisty suspense.

posts.title: What's Your Name?
posts.text: Children's books whose namesakes are proud to be who they are.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: February 28, 2016
posts.text: Are you in the mood for more gritty dystopian fiction with brooding, flawed characters? More twisty, unpredictable suspense series? More New York City crime series? Here are some recommendations for you.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: February 14, 2016
posts.text: This week's top five brings us new novels from popular series: NYPD Red, Ghostwalker, and the Mistborn.

posts.title: Presidential Biographies for Presidents' Day
posts.text: Here is a list of biographies that will take the reader well beyond high school history and National Gallery portraits to understand these men as anything but clear-cut themselves.

posts.title: Mental Health: A History
posts.text: The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), now in its fifth edition, is used as an authority for psychiatric diagnosis and is constantly under criticism, in controversy, or under revision. Clearly, the diagnosis of mental disorders in an ever-evolving practice. Here are a few books on the history of mental health.

posts.title: Bibliotherapy: A Little Self-Help
posts.text: If the gray days of winter have you feeling blue, try a little self-help reading. Warning! May cause mindfulness, self-awareness, and a better psychic state.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: January 24, 2016
posts.text: Did you love Girl on the Train? The Martian? All the Light We Cannot See? We've got some read alikes for you.

posts.title: Fascinating Histories
posts.text: Question: What do vitamins, autism, rain, the Chamber of Commerce, DARPA, St. Mark's Place, and the Vatican all have in common? Answer: Recently published, well researched, and reported histories.

posts.title: Unlikely Friendships in Children's Books
posts.text: Much like the gifs, memes, and images we find online, children's fiction is also full of unlikely animal friendships.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: January 10, 2015
posts.text: A repeat of last week, except The Girl on the Train and All the Light We Cannot See swapped spots. The top five still held strong throughout the holiday shopping.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: January 3, 2016
posts.text: A few popular titles that slipped off the list for a time are back this week: The Martian, The Girl on the Train, and All the Light We Cannot See.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: December 27, 2015
posts.text: Grisham, Patterson, Baldacci, Koontz and welcome back to The Martian this week in the top five.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: December 13, 2015
posts.text: Four thrillers, plus one romance to round out the list.

posts.title: NYPL Holiday Shopping Guide
posts.text: Happy Holidays! Here are some of our 2015 favorites for the readers on your list.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: November 22, 2015
posts.text: Los Angeles crime dominates the top five this week, follwed by some small town crime and survival on Mars.

posts.title: Lost in Place: Middle School Novels Set in NYC
posts.text: Here are a few contemporary titles that capture that sense of young, daring adventure in NYC.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: November 15, 2015
posts.text: Michael Connelly, Nora Roberts, Stephen King and John Grisham and The Martian rank in the top five. No strangers to the bestseller list this week.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: November 8, 2015
posts.text: A legal thriller and an intricately plotted gruesome mystery, Grisham and Galbraith join the top five this week.

posts.title: Introducing NoveList
posts.text: We’ve added a new service to our suite of recommendation tools: NoveList, an interactive database that specializes in readers’ advisory. So how do you use it?

posts.title: Kids Music That Won’t Make Parents Want To Die
posts.text: Kids have an amazing capacity for repetition. Here are a few collections of kids’ music to listen to around the house or in the car that you will be less likely to throw out the window upon the hundredth play.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: November 1, 2015
Back to the Bookish Future
posts.text: In 1985, Robert Zemeckis, Michael J. Fox, Christopher Lloyd and Crispin Glover brought time travel via DeLorean into the hearts and minds of Americans.  Here are a few more tales of time travel.

posts.title: Simon Winchester's Favorite Books
posts.text: Author Simon Winchester is our guest at LIVE from the NYPL on October 30 at 7 pm. We asked him to talk about his favorite books.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: October 25, 2015
posts.text: A compilation of George R.R. Martin novellas, prequels to A Song of Ice and Fire enters the top 5 this week, along with some a new installment of the Mistborn series and new Mitch Rapp novel.

posts.title: Elvis Costello's Favorite Books
posts.text: See Elvis Costello at LIVE from the NYPL  Friday October 16, at 7 p.m. Below Elvis answers some questions about himself as a reader.

posts.title: KidsLIVE! Interview with Jerry Craft
posts.text: Jerry Craft, author and illustrator of The Offenders: Saving the World While Serving Detention  as well as the illustrator of Patrik Henry Bass's The Zero Degree Zombie Zone is coming to KidsLIVE! October 22nd at the Riverdale Library. We were lucky enough to ask him a few questions.

posts.title: Middle Grade Horror
posts.text: Much like kids love the thrill they feel on a rollar coaster, young readers seek out books that appeal to their sense of terror and excitement. Browse this selection of quality scary, spine-chlling, unnerving books for middle grade readers.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: October 18, 2015
posts.text: From The Martian to The Murder House, and everything in between, here are some readalikes to quench your thrill thirst.

posts.title: Lovable Little Monsters
posts.text: Monsters are scary, sometimes, and sometimes they are courageous and adventurous and funny and mischievous.  Some kids might find themselves in these monster stories.  Those lovable little monsters!

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: October 11, 2015
posts.text: A novel centered around a wedding among the suspense titles in the top 5 this week.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: October 4, 2015
posts.text: The top five is suspense filled this week. Suspense in on Mars, in Sweden, and in the FBI. If  you want more, here are some recommendations for you. Enjoy!

posts.title: The Banned Books We Love
posts.text: Eleven of our favorite challenged titles.

posts.title: Origin Stories
posts.text: There are a couple kinds of origin stories. There are the backstories that super heroes have to explain how they got their powers. There are origin stories that describe how some reality came into existence. Our staff recommend some favorites here.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: September 27, 2015
posts.text: Jack Reacher is back! Lee Child's Make Me takes the number one spot this week. For fans of Reacher, we have some more cool characters.

posts.title: Board Books with Photographs
posts.text: We love children's book  illustrations and illustrators, but sometimes babies want the real thing.  Here are some board books to bring on those smiles and grabs.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: September 20, 2015
posts.text: An exciting new release, the fourth novel in the Millennium series, hits number one this week. If you finish it in one sitting and want more, here are some readalikes to get you through the rest of the week.

posts.title: Autumn Essays
posts.text: Fall is a great time for observation and refection. In that spirit, NYPL staff members selected their favorite essays to share with you.  Settle in and watch the leaves change and we hope you find something that resonates with you.

posts.title: Bicycle Books for Beginners
posts.text: Learning to ride a bike is a childhood rite of passage. Here a few titles to encourage kids through the many falls that precede those glorious, autonomous loops around the block or the park.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: September 13, 2015
posts.text: The twenty-fourth installment of the Kinsey Millhone detective series enters the top 5 this week, along with a new mystery set in Three Pines, and some romance for a single mom in the town of Thunder Point.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: September 6, 2015
posts.text: A couple of popular suspense series enter the top five this week with new additions.

posts.title: A Picture is Worth a Thousand Words: Wordless Picture Books
posts.text: Many parents feel intimidated when they first encounter a wordless picture book. Then the possibilities set in: the child can make up the story, the story can change from reading to reading. Not to mention,  the art in these wordless books is stunning.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: August 16, 2015
posts.text: Romances are selling big this week—second chance romance, paranormal romance, dominance and submission.  If any of these leave you longing for more, here are some read alikes to keep you satisfied.

posts.title: Middle Grade Mysteries
posts.text: Who better to go undetected than a seemingly innocent middle grader. If you have a budding sleuth at home (hint—she probably loves Scooby Doo Mystery Incorporated) here are some titles to hone her skills.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: August 9, 2015
posts.text: Finished Go Set a Watchman this weekend? Or The Girl On the Train? Looking for more? Here are this week's read alikes. Enjoy!

posts.title: Children's Books Set in Libraries
posts.text: For many children, libraries are among their first social places. A place where the furniture is their size, where they can be among their peers, and follow their curiosity. Here are a few children's books set in libraries. If you have a library kid, these titles will make them feel right at home.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: August 2, 2015
posts.text: A highly anticipated prequel and sequel this week! If either or both leave you wanting more, we've got you covered. Enjoy!

posts.title: Middle School, Multiple Perspectives
posts.text: Books composed of multiple narrators may help tweens grow empathy as they learn to navigate the complex social structure that is middle school.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: July 26, 2015
posts.text: If you are among the many who read and enjoyed one of these titles and are looking to repeat that headlong rush to the end or feeling of falling in love with a character, here are a few read alikes to keep you going. Enjoy!

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: July 19, 2015
posts.text: Here are the bestselling fiction titles from the New York Times for the week of July 19, 2015. If you are among the thousands who read and enjoyed these books, and you want to repeat that feeling of suspense or romance, here are a few read alikes to keep you going. Enjoy!

posts.title: If You Like Mo Willems...
posts.text: We love Mo Willems for so many reasons: 1.) He is silly 2.) His books are character driven 3.) He uses art to make his characters expressive, 4.) His books beg the reader to participate in the storytelling, and 5.) He focuses on issues we grapple with (still!) as adults.

posts.title: Summer Shorts
posts.text: Twelve staff members here at the library selected a short story. We recorded them each reading the story and talking about the reason behind their selections. We will release one story per week for the entire summer.

posts.title: Books for the Twenty-Somethings
posts.text: Can you recommend any books with female protagonists who are in their early to mid-20s?

posts.title: Asian-Pacific American Heritage Picks for Adults
posts.text: It is Asian-Pacific American Heritage Month, so to celebrate these writers we asked our staff here at NYPL to name some of their favorites. Here is what they had to say.

posts.title: Asian-Pacific American Heritage Picks for Young Readers
posts.text: It is Asian-Pacific American Heritage Month, so to celebrate these writers we asked our staff to name some of their favorites for kids, middle grade and YA readers. Here is what they had to say.

posts.title: Salute to Narrative Nonfiction: Journalism and Social Sciences
posts.text: Narrative or creative nonfiction is somewhat newly recognized genre. Naturally, as librarians we have a great appreciation for the research, the primary source documents and interviews, but it is the narrative, the skillful pacing, the phrasing, and the insight that make it read like a thriller that set these books apart from other nonfiction.

posts.title: Happy Mother's Day to Our Reading Role Models
posts.text: For Mother's Day, we asked our staff to tell us something about their mothers and share her favorite book, or a book they remember reading with her as a child. Here is what they had to say:

posts.title: Ask the Author: Sally Mann
posts.text: Sally Mann comes to Books at Noon next Wednesday, May 13 to discuss her latest work, Hold Still: A Memoir With Photographs. We asked her six questions about what she likes to read.

posts.title: Our Favorite New York Stories for Kids and Teens
posts.text: The staff at New York Public Library love their city. Here are some books for young children, middle graders, and teens they feel deliver all the charm, mystique, and humanity that makes this place great.

posts.title: Our Favorite New York Stories
posts.text: The staff at the New York Public Library loves their city as well as a story that captures what is truly special and wonderful about this place. Here are a few of their favorites.

posts.title: Salute to Narrative Nonfiction: Memoirs
posts.text: Narrative or creative nonfiction is somewhat newly recognized genre. Naturally, as librarians we have a great appreciation for the research, the primary source documents and interviews, but it is the narrative, the skillful pacing, the phrasing, and the insight that make it read like a thriller that set these books apart from other nonfiction.

posts.title: Ask the Author: Alan Cumming
posts.text: Alan Cumming comes to Books at Noon next Wednesday, May 6 to discuss his latest work, Not My Father's Son. We asked him six questions about what he likes to read.

posts.title: Books to Read Before Kindergarten
posts.text: We asked our Children’s Librarians to select three books every child should know about before kindergarten. Here are their picks.

posts.title: Salute to Narrative Nonfiction: Travel and Adventure
posts.text: Narrative or creative nonfiction is a somewhat newly recognized genre. Naturally, as librarians we have a great appreciation for the research, the primary source documents and interviews, but it is the narrative, the skillful pacing, the phrasing, and the insight that make it read like a thriller that set these books apart from other nonfiction.

posts.title: Ask the Author: Jorie Graham
posts.text: Jorie Graham has a new collection of her work out this Spring entitled From the New World: Poems 1976-2014. We asked her six questions about what she likes to read.

posts.title: Celebrating World Book Day with Stories of the Immigrant Experience
posts.text: This year to celebrate we asked the staff to think about their favorite stories about people who have come to live in the United States from another country. Here are their recommendations.

posts.title: Salute to Narrative Nonfiction: Science
posts.text: Narrative or creative nonfiction is a somewhat newly recognized genre.Naturally, as librarians we have a great appreciation for the research, the primary source documents and interviews, but it is the narrative, the skillful pacing, the phrasing, and the insight that make it read like a thriller that set these books apart from other nonfiction.

posts.title: Ask the Author: Chigozie Obioma
posts.text: Chigozie Obioma comes to Books at Noon next Wednesday, April 22 to discuss his latest work, The Fishermen. We asked him six questions about what he likes to read.

posts.title: Ask the Author: Akhil Sharma
posts.text: Akhil Sharma comes to Books at Noon next Wednesday, April 15 to discuss his latest work, Family Life: A Novel. We asked him six questions about what he likes to read.

posts.title: Books for a New Utopia
posts.text: Imagine an apocalypse that doesn't destroy the people or the planet, just everything we have built and all knowledge/memory of building it. What books would you like to survive to guide in the building of a new utopia? Why that book?

posts.title: Our Favorite Female Characters
Anticipation: Upcoming Titles
These Books Opened Our Eyes to Another Culture
posts.text: Our reader asked us for a book that would open her eyes to a new culture. Here are the titles our staff recommended.

posts.title: 30 Days of Poetry
posts.text: April is National Poetry Month! To celebrate here at The New York Public Library we recorded thirty of our librarians and other staff members reading a favorite poem.

posts.title: Agatha Christie's Top 5 Plot Twists
posts.text: Agatha Christie introduced a number of classic motifs to the crime/mystery genre. A murder is committed, there are many suspects, each harboring a shameful secret, and the detective reveals these secrets one by one throughout the story saving the most shocking twists for the end. These are our top five most surprising Agatha Christie mysteries. Which are yours?

posts.title: Ask the Author: T.C. Boyle
posts.text: T.C. Boyle comes to Books at Noon next Wednesday, April 1 to discuss his latest work, The Harder They Come. We asked him six questions about what he likes to read.

posts.title: Some of Our Favorite Authors
posts.text: It's Women's History month so we asked our staff to name some of their favorite female writers and tell us which (of hers) is their favorite work.

posts.title: We Are Warriors: Biographies of Brave Women
posts.text: It is March and we are again celebrating Women’s History Month. One of our bravest and most beautiful writers (who is also a woman) once wrote: “You may write me down in history / With your bitter, twisted lies, / You may trod me in the very dirt / But still, like dust, I’ll rise.” Here are the titles of biographies of brave warriors (who are also women.)

posts.title: Ask the Author: Frank Bruni
posts.text: Frank Bruni comes to Books at Noon next Wednesday, March 18 to discuss his latest work, Where You Go Is Not Who You’ll Be: An Antidote to the College Admissions Mania. We asked him six questions about what he likes to read.

posts.title: Feminism Unfinished
posts.text: Here are some titles to help us all consider both how far we have come and how far we have to go.

posts.title: Not Just Coming Out Stories
posts.text: Our reader asked us for "recommendations for gay fiction that is NOT erotica and also not just coming out stories?" Here are a few suggestions from our staff.

posts.title: Our Suggestions for Facebook's "A Year of Books"
posts.text: Mark Zuckerberg has committed to reading two books a month in 2015, "with an emphasis on learning about different cultures, beliefs, histories and technologies.” Here's what we recommend he check out.

posts.title: Snow Day Reads
posts.text: New York City is once again bracing itself for snow. Here in Readers Services we are doing our part by making sure you have some good snowy day reading. Here are some titles for all ages.

posts.title: Selma Reading List
posts.text: A reading list for all ages to accompany the movie Selma.

posts.title: Graphic Memoirs
posts.text: Our reader asked: I'm looking for my next great read. I'm a fan of graphic novels that function as memoirs, or even semi-autobiographical fiction that's realistic. I've really enjoyed Persepolis, Marbles, This One Summer, and One Bad Rat. What should I put on my list to read next?

posts.title: Anticipation: Upcoming Titles
posts.text: We are excited about the New Year and some promising new titles coming out early this year. Here are a few we look forward to getting our hands on here in Readers Services.

posts.title: NYPL's Best Books of 2014
posts.text: We asked our staff here at the New York Public Library to tell us about the best book they read this year.

posts.title: NYPL Staff Picks (Available in "E")
posts.text: Recent ebooks in several genres available to check out.

posts.title: Noteworthy Debut Novels 2014
posts.text: Home run, first time at bat! Here are a few debut novels published this year (2014) that are also worth a look.

posts.title: Other Great YA Books
posts.text: Our reader asked: "I have read and loved all the popular YA books out there: We Were Liars, If I Stay, The Fault In Our Stars... What else do you have for me?"

posts.title: Accessible Classics
posts.text: One of our readers asks: Hi NYPL! I am looking to beef up my reading resume with some "classics." Only, time is precious and I don't want to be bored out of my skull. What "classics" do you think a 21st century person can really dig into?

posts.title: Memoirs with Recipes
posts.text: Memoirs with recipes: two great book categories that taste great together!

posts.title: Books We Are Thankful For
posts.text: We talked to librarians to find out the books they are most thankful for this year.

posts.title: Children's Librarians' Favorite Halloween Books
posts.text: Our Halloween favorites to read and share with kids.

posts.title: Ask the Author: Sam Roberts
posts.text: Sam Roberts comes to Books at Noon to discuss his latest work, A History of New York in 101 Objects.  Here he tells us a bit about himself as a reader.

posts.title: Page-Turners for All Tastes
posts.text: Our reader asked us to recommend a good page turner for a long plane ride. Here are some titles you will want to read in one sitting from a variety of genres.

posts.title: Three is the Magic Number: Trilogies You May Not Have Known Were Trilogies
posts.text: The Hunger Games, Divergent, Stieg Larsson's Millenium trilogy—when you cannot get enough of a character or just don't want the story to end, three is a welcome number. These popular trilogies need no further introduction, but here are some titles you may be surprised to learn, are also part of a trilogy.

posts.title: Looking for Authentic Voices
posts.text: This week's readers advisory request comes to us as a list of books. The reader says that for her, a good book is language driven and the voice should ring through as authentic. Do we have any authentic voices for this reader?

posts.title: Suburban Malaise
posts.text: Suburban – an adjective meaning contemptibly dull and ordinary. Malaise – a noun meaning a general feeling of discomfort, illness, or uneasiness whose exact cause is difficult to identify.

posts.title: Ask the Author: Philip K. Howard
posts.text: Philip K. Howard came to  Books at Noon to discuss his latest work, The Rule of Nobody.

posts.title: If You Like Murakami...
posts.text:
This week's readers advisory request comes to us in the form of two books and an author our reader has enjoyed in the past: The Secret History, Jonathan Strange and Mr. Norrell, and Haruki Murakami. 

Here is what our staff recommended for this reader.

posts.title: Ask the Author: Maira Kalman
posts.text: Maira Kalman is our next guest at Books at Noon this week.

posts.title: Our Favorite Spooky Tales
posts.text: If you are looking for a spooky Halloween read, the staff at the New York Public Library have some suggestions for you.

posts.title: If You Like LOTR, GoT, and American Gods, Here's What to Read Next
posts.text: If you liked Lord of the Rings, Game of Thrones, and American Gods… here are some fantasy titles to consider reading next.

posts.title: Ask the Author: Jane Smiley
posts.text: Jane Smiley comes to Books at Noon this week to discuss her latest work, Some Luck.

posts.title: When the Print Book Would Take Up Your Whole Bag... Try an eBook
posts.text: So long, but so worth it. Give your shoulders a break and pick up the e-book version instead.

posts.title: E-books for the 6-12 Set
posts.text: Five recommendations from our e-book collection.

posts.title: Missing The Killing? Crime Series Set in the Northwest
posts.text: There is something about the sinister, shadowy, gray atmosphere of The Killing that is unforgettable. Detectives eat in the rain and smoke in the rain. Rain falls heavy on the windshield day and night. Here are some books with this same sense of atmosphere.

posts.title: Ask the Author: Mark Strand
posts.text: Mark Strand answers our six questions about reading.

posts.title: Contemporary Southern Writers
posts.text: Seven recent books by Southern writers.

posts.title: Ask the Author: Susan Minot
posts.text: Susan Minot likes to read paper pages and other real things. She comes to Books at Noon on Wednesday, September 24 to discuss her latest work, Thirty Girls.

posts.title: 10 Pirate Romances for Talk Like a Pirate Day
posts.text: Heroines on the high seas say "shiver me timbers" for these swashbuckling titles.

posts.title: 10 Very Scottish Books
posts.text: Today as Scotland votes on independence, a list of Scottish favorites.

posts.title: Tycoons: Real and Imagined
posts.text: Whether you're a penny pincher or a big spender, tycoons offer a wealth of fascinating stories. These books, both fiction and nonfiction, dramatize big business. From captains of industry to investment bankers, these money bags characters have stories worth their weight in gold.

posts.title: From Boyhood to Beyond: Books About the Passage of Time
posts.text: Richard Linklater's new movie Boyhood was filmed with the same cast over the course of twelve years. Here are some novels that also concern themselves with the passing of time, from Proust's masterpiece Swann's Way to contemporary popular fiction like Mitch Albom's The Time Keeper.

posts.title: Imposters: Real and Imagined
posts.text: Whether you're interested in teasing out the differences between appearances and reality or you just like a good thriller, our favorite scam stories will make you look at charming strangers in a whole new light.

posts.title: The Leftovers Reading List
posts.text: Before it was an HBO hit, The Leftovers was a book by Tom Perrotta. Each episode revolves around one of the four members of the Garvey family, following a mysterious "rapture" that disappeared 2% of the world's population. Before you start to binge or after you are finished here are some other books featuring interconnected stories you might enjoy.

posts.title: Books Hotter Than NYC Summer Afternoons
posts.text: Summer in New York City can feel like the most unbearably hot place on earth. The subway platforms seem to sizzle, and the pavement? It's laughing at our misery.

posts.title: Beat the Heat with 8 Chilling Mysteries
posts.text: Summer in New York can leave you melting into the pavement. That's why a mystery that chills you to the bone may be the best thing you do to beat the heat this season.
